questions.question_text: A Cisco WLC is deployed to a customer site. The customer provides a list of wired and wireless subnets that must be allowed to pass through the WLC. What is the path in the WLC user interface to create the access list?

choices.C: Controller > Interfaces > ACL Name drop-down list
choices.D: WLANs > WLAN ID > Advanced > Override Interface ACL
choices.B: Security > Access Control Lists > Access Control Lists
choices.A: Security > Access Control Lists > CPU Access Control Lists

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
To create an access control list (ACL) on a Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) that allows specific wired and wireless subnets to pass through, the correct path in the WLC user interface is:

Navigate to Security > Access Control Lists > Access Control Lists:

This is where you can create and manage ACLs on the WLC. ACLs are used to control traffic based on source and destination IP addresses, protocols, and ports.

Create the ACL:

Add rules to the ACL to permit or deny traffic from the specified subnets.

Apply the ACL:

After creating the ACL, it can be applied to interfaces, WLANs, or other components as needed.

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
A. Security > Access Control Lists > CPU Access Control Lists:

This option is used to create ACLs that control traffic to the CPU of the WLC, not for general traffic filtering.

C. Controller > Interfaces > ACL Name drop-down list:

This option is used to apply an existing ACL to an interface, not to create a new ACL.

D. WLANs > WLAN ID > Advanced > Override Interface ACL:

This option is used to apply an ACL to a specific WLAN, overriding the interface ACL. It does not allow you to create a new ACL.

questions.question_text: A company wants to utilize the wireless network to push videos to wireless clients. An engineer has been hired to configure a Cisco WLC to notify users when it cannot provide a video stream while using the Multicast Direct Feature. Which setting must be enabled for this functionality?

comments.content:
(B) Northbound Notification ‚ùå

Northbound notifications are for external management applications (e.g., Cisco Prime or DNA Center) to collect WLC data, not for notifying clients.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Cisco WLC Multicast Direct (also known as 802.11v Multicast-to-Unicast) is used to optimize video streaming to wireless clients by converting multicast video traffic into multiple unicast streams.

When Session Announcement State is enabled, the WLC notifies clients when it cannot provide a video stream due to network constraints, such as insufficient bandwidth or excessive traffic load.

This setting helps improve the Quality of Experience (QoE) by informing users about potential video streaming issues.

Selected Answer: B
To notify users when the Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) cannot provide a video stream while using the Multicast Direct Feature, the Northbound Notification setting must be enabled. Here's why:

Northbound Notification:

This feature allows the WLC to send notifications to external systems (e.g., network management systems, applications) when specific events occur, such as the inability to provide a video stream. These notifications can be used to alert users or administrators about the issue.

Multicast Direct Feature:

This feature enables the WLC to forward multicast traffic directly to clients without converting it to unicast. If the WLC cannot provide the video stream (e.g., due to insufficient bandwidth or network issues), Northbound Notifications can be used to inform users.

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
A. SNMP Trap Log:

SNMP traps are used for network monitoring and management but are not designed to notify end users directly.

C. Message of the Day:

The Message of the Day (MOTD) is a static message displayed to users when they log in. It cannot dynamically notify users about video stream issues.

D. Session Announcement State:

This setting is related to multicast session announcements but does not provide user notifications for video stream issues.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The Work Centers option in Cisco ISE, which contains the Device Administration pages, is only available if the appropriate TACACS+ licenses are installed. Here's why:

TACACS+ Licenses:

Cisco ISE requires specific licenses to enable TACACS+ functionality. Without these licenses, the Device Administration Work Center and related features will not be available.

Work Centers:

The Work Centers in Cisco ISE provide centralized management for specific functionalities, such as device administration, network access, and posture assessment. The Device Administration Work Center is essential for configuring and managing TACACS+ services.

comments.content:
A. Open ports 1812 and 1813:

Ports 1812 and 1813 are used for RADIUS, not TACACS+. While these ports may need to be open for RADIUS functionality, they are unrelated to the availability of the Device Administration Work Center.

B. Enable the Work Centers option for AAA:

The Work Centers option is not something that can be manually enabled or disabled. It becomes available when the appropriate licenses are installed.

D. Configure a shared secret key in Cisco ISE:

While configuring a shared secret key is necessary for TACACS+ communication between devices and Cisco ISE, it does not resolve the issue of the missing Work Centers option.

choices.D: Configure a shared secret key in Cisco ISE.
choices.B: Enable the Work Centers option for AAA.

questions.question_text: A company uses Cisco ACS to provide AAA services to network devices. The company recently replaced Cisco ACS with Cisco ISE that runs TACACS+. An IT administrator notices that the Work Centers option that contains the device administration pages is unavailable. Which action resolves the issue?

A customer uses a Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series Wireless Controller and Cisco 802.11ax APs. The management has requested the ability to see what type of devices are on the wireless network. Which two types of local device profiling must be used? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: DE
Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series Wireless Controllers support local device profiling to classify wireless clients based on specific attributes. The two most effective profiling methods for identifying device types are:

DHCP Profiling (D) üèÜ

The WLC inspects DHCP request packets from clients.
The DHCP Option 55 (Parameter Request List) and Option 60 (Vendor Class Identifier) contain device-specific information.
This helps classify clients as iPhones, Android devices, Windows PCs, printers, etc.
MAC Address OUI (E) üîç

The Organizationally Unique Identifier (OUI) is the first 24 bits of a device‚Äôs MAC address and is assigned to manufacturers (e.g., Apple, Samsung, Cisco).
The WLC uses this information to categorize devices by vendor.

comments.content:
(B) Wireless supplicant ‚ùå

The supplicant is responsible for authentication (e.g., 802.1X/EAP) but does not provide profiling information.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BE
To identify the types of devices on the wireless network using local device profiling on a Cisco Catalyst 9800 Series Wireless Controller, the following profiling methods must be used:

Wireless Supplicant:

The wireless supplicant (e.g., the software on the client device that handles wireless connectivity) provides information about the device type, operating system, and other attributes. This information can be used to profile the device.

MAC Address OUI:

The MAC Address OUI (Organizationally Unique Identifier) is the first three bytes of a MAC address and identifies the manufacturer of the device. This can be used to determine the type of device (e.g., Apple, Samsung, Dell).

comments.content:
Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
A. IP Address:

The IP address does not provide information about the type of device. It is used for routing and addressing but not for device profiling.

C. RADIUS:

RADIUS is used for authentication, authorization, and accounting (AAA) but does not provide device profiling information.

D. DHCP:

While DHCP can provide some information (e.g., hostname), it is not as reliable or detailed as wireless supplicant or MAC Address OUI for device profiling.

choices.D: The controller sends every multicast packet associated APS.
choices.A: The controller sends multicast packets to a user group.
choices.B: Packet replication is performed on the controller.
choices.C: Packet replication is performed on the network.

questions.question_text: What is characteristic of multicast mode that affects the wireless network when configured on a Cisco WLC?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Multicast mode on a Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) impacts the network in the following ways:

Efficient Packet Delivery ‚úÖ

In multicast mode, the WLC sends only one copy of a multicast packet to a multicast group address.
The network infrastructure (switches and routers) then replicates and forwards the packets to APs that have subscribed to the multicast group.
Reduces Controller Load ‚úÖ

Unlike unicast mode, where the WLC sends a separate copy of a multicast packet to each AP, multicast mode shifts the replication process to the network, reducing the burden on the WLC.
Requires Multicast Routing Configuration ‚úÖ

The network must support PIM (Protocol Independent Multicast) and have IGMP snooping enabled for efficient delivery.

comments.content:
(B) Packet replication is performed on the controller. ‚ùå

This describes unicast mode, where the WLC replicates the multicast packet and sends individual copies to each AP.

Why the Other Options Are Incorrect:
A. The controller sends multicast packets to a user group:

While the WLC does send multicast packets to clients, the key characteristic is that packet replication is performed on the controller, not just sending packets to a user group.

C. Packet replication is performed on the network:

Packet replication is not performed on the network; it is handled by the WLC to ensure efficient delivery to APs and clients.

D. The controller sends every multicast packet associated APS:

This is not accurate. The WLC only sends multicast packets to APs that have clients subscribed to the multicast group, and it handles packet replication internally.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When multicast mode is configured on a Cisco Wireless LAN Controller (WLC), the following characteristic affects the wireless network:

Packet Replication is Performed on the Controller:

In multicast mode, the WLC receives a single multicast stream from the network and replicates it for each Access Point (AP) that has clients subscribed to the multicast group. This ensures that multicast traffic is efficiently delivered to all interested clients without flooding the entire network.
